<target_code>
Here is the code of check_apply_param__threads:
```c
static void
check_apply_param__threads (void)
{
  if (0 == tool_params.threads)
    return;

  num_threads = tool_params.threads;

  if (get_process_cpu_core_count () < num_threads)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "WARNING: The requested number of threads (%u) is "
             "higher than the number of detected available CPU cores (%u).\n",
             num_threads, get_process_cpu_core_count ());
    fprintf (stderr, "This decreases the performance. "
             "Consider using fewer threads.\n");
  }
  if (get_cpu_core_count () == num_threads)
  {
    printf ("The requested number of threads is equal to the number of "
            "detected CPU cores.\n");
    print_all_cores_used ();
  }
}
```

explanation: Only function calls can produce direct or indirect recursion that would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2. The fragments selected are all call sites in this function (two condition checks that invoke other functions, three I/O calls, and the call to print_all_cores_used). Other parts of the function do not need investigation for Rule 17.2: the early return (if (0 == tool_params.threads) return;), the assignment (num_threads = tool_params.threads;), the numeric comparisons, and the string literals cannot create recursion by themselves and therefore are not relevant to Rule 17.2.
